story.kicker_image_caption: BJP chief Amit Shah wants the party to make inroads in the coastal states, where it has won 15 of 190 LS seats.
story.storykicker: The Bharatiya Janata Party has come up with Project Coromandel, which is aimed at gaining new political ground in states where the party has not been able to make inroads.
story.storybody:
The BJP is playing the long game. In the throes of celebration after its spectacular Assam assembly election victory, it has not lost view of its less-than-expected show in Kerala, West Bengal and Tamil Nadu. 

To correct the lopsided spread of the party in certain regions, it has come up with 'Project Coromandel'. 

'IDEA IS TO GAIN NEW POLITICAL GROUND'

A top party leader, requesting anonymity, told MAIL TODAY that the project is a rough reference to a geographical area stretched  along the entire east coast from TN to Odisha, then touching Bengal and going right up to the Northeast. Here, the party has not been able to make inroads. It bagged only about 15 of the 190 Lok Sabha seats in this geography in 2014 despite the saffron wave in rest of the country. It wants to change that in 2019. 

The idea is to gain new political ground and offset the possible losses, even if marginal, in such states where it did incredibly well in 2014. 

The Coromandel Coast refers to the southeastern coastal region of the India, between the Eastern Ghats and the Bay of Bengal of the Indian Ocean. 

Therefore, the regions that would be targeted politically under the project would be the states of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, West Bengal and a logical political extension to the NE hills. 

'AMIT SHAH WANTS PARTY TO MAKE INROADS'

"In the six states of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, West Bengal and Arunachal Pradesh, there are a total of 190 parliamentary seats, out of which the BJP has only 15. On the other hand, in UP we bagged 71 of 80. In MP, we won 27 out of 29. But the BJP chief Amit Shah wants the party to make inroads in the coastal states, where it has won 15 of 190 LS seats. point is that we might not be able to better these numbers in 2019 Lok Sabha elections; we may lose some," said the top BJP functionary. 

"We need to expand to regions and states where we have not yet made inroads into and where there is a scope of expansion. This way we would be able to make up for the losses in the states where we performed spectacularly." 

The upcoming National Executive meet of the party in Allahabad on June 12-13 would not just be about making a statement regarding the UP elections, but the Coromandel project too will come up for discussion. 

Another BJP leader, asking not to be named, said national general secretary and Assam in-charge Ram Madhav has been entrusted to bring his political acumen to the project.

 Also read: Speeding Coromandel Express mows down six elephants in Odisha

Ram Madhav has been entrusted to bring his political acumen to the project
